articles.title: Shandiya Balasubramaniam

shandiya balasubramaniam
          
          
          about

          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            Shandiya Balasubramaniam
          
          
            
              I’m a data scientist and evolutionary ecologist based in Melbourne, Australia. I’m currently working as a geospatial data analyst in the environmental space. My ecological research integrates molecular biology, conservation management, and wildlife disease ecology to understand adaptive responses to environmental variation in threatened species. When I’m not coding for work or looking at birds, I enjoy making art in R.
            
            
              I’m a data scientist and evolutionary ecologist based in Melbourne, Australia. I’m currently working as a geospatial data analyst in the environmental space. My ecological research integrates molecular biology, conservation management, and wildlife disease ecology to understand adaptive responses to environmental variation in threatened species. When I’m not coding for work or looking at birds, I enjoy making art in R.

articles.title: Projects
articles.description: A space for my projects, some personal and some professional
articles.contents:
h1, h3, p {
  text-align: right;
}






Manky Parrots
Manky Parrots is a citizen science project that aims to map the incidence of psittacine beak and feather disease (PBFD) in Australia, to better understand the spread of this disease in the wild. Visible signs of infection include deformation of the beak, claws and feathers. Sightings can be logged here, and if you’d like more information about this project, please get in contact at MankyParrot@gmail.com.





feathers
feathers is an R package that contains colour palettes inspired by the plumage of Australian birds. For species exhibiting sexual dimorphism (i.e. males and females look different), I have used female colours. Research on birds has historically been biased towards males, and the choice to use female colours in this package is my way of highlighting the often-overlooked beauty of female birds.





rtistry
Sometimes I make art in R, and sometimes I post it on Twitter with the #rtistry tag. If you’re interested in the code behind the images, you can find it on GitHub.





30DayMapChallenge
The #30DayMapChallenge was initiated by Topi Tjukanov in November 2019. My contributions to the 2021 challenge are here.

articles.title: Publications
articles.contents:
Peer-reviewed publications
Boysen K, Perkins SL, Hunjan S, Oliver P, Gardner M, Balasubramaniam S, J Melville. Diversity and phylogenetic relationships of haemosporidian and hemogregarine parasites in Australian lizards. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution, in press
Balasubramaniam S, Mulder RA, Sunnucks P, Pavlova A, Melville J (2017) MHC class II β exon 2 variation in pardalotes (Pardalotidae) is shaped by selection, recombination and gene conversion. Immunogenetics 69: 101-111.
Balasubramaniam S, Bray RD, Mulder RA, Sunnucks P, Pavlova A, Melville J (2016) New data from basal Australian songbird lineages show that complex structure of MHC class II β genes has early evolutionary origins within passerines. BMC Evolutionary Biology 16:112.
Balasubramaniam S, Mulder RA, Sunnucks P, Pavlova A, Amos JN, Melville J (2013) Prevalence and diversity of avian haematozoa in three species of Australian passerine. Emu 113:353-358.
Amos N, Balasubramaniam S, Grootendorst L, Harrisson K, Lill A, Mac Nally RC, Pavlova A, Radford JQ, Takeuchi N, Thomson JR, Sunnucks P (2013) Little evidence that condition, stress indicators, sex ratio, or homozygosity are related to landscape or habitat attributes in declining woodland birds. Journal of Avian Biology 44:45-54.
Balasubramaniam S, Guay P-J (2008) Purple swamphens (Porphyrio porphyrio) attempting to prey upon black swan (Cygnus atratus) eggs and preying upon a cygnet on an urban lake in Melbourne, Australia. Wilson Journal of Ornithology 120:633-635.
Technical reports
Balasubramaniam S, Sumner J (2021) Genetic analysis of captive and wild populations of the Bush Stone-curlew Burhinus grallarius. Technical report prepared for DELWP. 29 pp. 
Balasubramaniam S (2020) Plains-wanderer genetic analysis: A comparison of wild and captive-bred individuals. Technical report prepared for Plains-wanderer National Recovery Team. 19 pp. 
Balasubramaniam S (2020) Population structure in the Hooded Plover Thinornis cucullatus. Technical report prepared for BirdLife Australia. 18 pp. 
Rowe K, Balasubramaniam S (2020) Plains-wanderer acoustic monitoring: song meter detection space. Technical report prepared for DELWP. 16 pp. 
Balasubramaniam S (2019) Genetic analysis of the Plains-wanderer Pedionomus torquatus. Technical report prepared for Zoos Victoria and Taronga Conservation Society Australia. 19 pp.
Theses
Balasubramaniam S (2015) Evolution and ecology of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) genes in south-eastern Australian passerines. Doctoral Thesis. School of BioSciences, The University of Melbourne.
Balasubramaniam S (2007) Male incubation effort and extra-pair paternity in the Black Swan (Cygnus atratus). Honours Thesis. School of BioSciences, The University of Melbourne.
